Translated from Vietnamese by Anh H. Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hoàng Thị Nghĩa, 40 tuổi, sống cùng chồng tại xã Bắc Phú, huyện Sóc Sơn. Chị Nghĩa tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1995. Các vòng vốn đầu chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và dịch vụ cho thuê bát đĩa phông bạt dùng cho đám hiếu, hỷ. Từ năm 2000 chị chuyển sang nghề chụp ảnh, trang điểm cô dâu, cho thuê áo cưới. Thu nhập kinh doanh có sự thay đổi rõ rệt tăng lên mức 300USD/tháng. Ngoài ra, anh Thiệp, chồng chị còn làm thêm bảo vệ cho UBND xã nên kinh tế gia đình rất ổn định. Kinh tế phát triển, 2 con của anh chị đều được tạo điều kiện cho học hành đến nơi đến chốn. Hai cháu nhiều năm liên tiếp đạt học sinh giỏi, và hiện nay đang theo học đại học Y và đại học Kinh tế trên Hà nội. Nguyện vọng của chị Nghĩa là được tham gia Quỹ lâu dài và mãi mãi. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 1200USD để mua phông nền chụp ảnh và váy áo cưới.

loans.use: Buy wedding-dress and background picture

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia, besides working for a public department, sells beauty products for a living, relying on her family and friend’s support for having a successful business. She wishes to increase her capital in order to offer a greater quantity and variety of products, with the aim of settling into a business space in a shopping center so that she can better manage her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

SONIA, además de desempeñarse para un departamento público se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza de manera contando con la importante ayuda para un exitoso desempeño con su entorno familiar y amical.Tiene el noble deseo de incrementar su capital para ofertar mayor cantidad y variedad de artículos a fin de establecerse en un espacio dentro de un centro comercial para mejor administración de sus ganacias.

loans.use: Increase capital to offer a greater quantity and variety of products

loans.name: Yanapampa Group

texts.es:
The Communal Yanapampa Bank recently opened with 15 partners, all of whom are from the Community of Yanapampa belonging to the District of HuamanguilL., 40 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. The inhabitants of this community work in agriculture, care of livestock, and livestock trading.

The partners are involved in agriculture; care of livestock; sale of tara tree agricultural products, pigs, sheep, goats and cattle; and carpentry service.

The partners require different levels of loans, comprising the total loan amount for the Communal Bank.

The loan proceeds will be applied toward the purchase of fertilizer, sheep, goats, piglets, and tara trees.

The dream of the partners is that their business will grow, that they will have more capital, and that their sons and daughters will have a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Yanapampa es un Banco que recién inicia con 15 socias, todos ellos son L. D. L. Comunidad D. Yanapampa que pertenece al Distrito D. HuamanguilL., que se encuentra a 40 minutos D. L. ciudad D. Ayacucho. Los pobladores D. esta comunidad se dedican a L. agricultura, crianza D. animales, L. compra y venta D. animales.

Las socias realizan diversos negocios como L. agricultura, L. crianza D. animales, venta D. tara, cochinilL., animales menores, ganado vacuno y el servicio D. carpintería.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, haciendo un total D. 6300 soles en el Banco Comunal.

Sus préstamos serán invertidos en L. compra D. abonos, ganado ovino, caprino, tara, cochinilL..

Los sueños D. las socias es que sus negocios sean más grandes, sus hijos tengan una buena educación y tener más capital.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer, sheep, goats, piglets, and tara trees

loans.name: Grupo Confianza - Teofila, Rene, Keita Group

texts.es:
TeofiL., Keita and Renee are members of the Confianza (Confidence) Communal Bank (first loan: www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1).

TeofiL. is married, 58 years old and has 12 children. She sells wool, cheese and meat at an outdoor stand at the Chorro market.

Keite lives with her common-law husband, is 27 years old and has three children. She sells firewood out of her home, and also purchases grains to ship out of town.

Renee lives with her common-law husband, is 36 years old and has two children. She's dedicated to making curtains and linings for furniture. Her store is located in her mother-in-law's home.

TeofiL., Keita and Renee are requesting loans of 1000, 800 and 1000 soles, respectively, which they plan to use to purchase wool, cheese, barley, wheat, fabrics and accessories.

The three women dream of improving and growing their businesses, and having their own home and a store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=30238&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

TeofiL., Keita y Renee son socias del Banco Comunal Confianza.

TeofiL. es casada, tiene 58 años y 12 hijos, TeofiL. venD. lana D. oveja, queso, carne D. manera ambulatoria en el M. Chorro.

Por otro lado Keita es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 3 hijos, Keita venD. leña en su casa. Además Keita compra cereales y luego envía a Pisco.

Mientras que Renee es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Renee se dedica a L. confección D. cortinas, forros para muebles, su tienda esta ubicado en L. casa D. su suegra.

TeofiL., Keita y Renee necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 800 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. lana, queso, cebada, trigo, telas y accesorios.

Los sueños D. TeofiL., Keita y Renee son mejorar su negocio, tener casa propia, tener una tienda y ampliar su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase wool, cheese, barley, wheat, fabrics and accessories / Teofila, Keita y Renee necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 800 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana, queso, cebada, trigo, telas y accesorios.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in a collection of chic purses to resell in her community

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
Mr. Jose is 34 years old, married to his wife, Adela, and has three young children.

Jose buys and sells musical instruments and accessories, and has been doing so for the past 7 years. He inherited this job from this parents, who continue working in the music business, and frequently travel to Argentina to import the merchandise. Adela works in the production of sleeves or cases for guitars and harps, using a special machine.

Mr. Jose is asking for the loan to purchase string, tuning pegs, and guitars.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Jose tiene 34 años, esta casado con la señora Adela y tienen 3 hijos todos menores de edad.

El Sr. Jose se dedica a la compra y venta de instrumentos y accesorios musicales hace 7 años, este trabajo lo heredero de sus padres quien hasta la actualidad siguen trabajando en lo mismo viajando a la Argentina como mayoristas e importando las mercaderías. Adela se dedica a la confección de las fundas o estuches para las guitarra y arpas con una maquina industrial que tienen en la casa especial para este tipo de costuras.

El Sr. Jose solicita este crédito para la compra de accesorios como cuerda, clavija y guitarras.

loans.use: Purchase musical instruments and accessories.

loans.name: Kimleng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimleng S. is 38 years old and sells sugar cane juice and raises pigs, earning about US$3.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Ok Kosal, 30 years old, sells icecream door to door, and also distills alcohol at home, earning US$3.00 per day. They both have two children, two of whom are students, and they live in Snam Pras Commune, Pursat Province.

Mrs. Kimleng decided to request a loan US$500 to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband's business and to also purchase five pigs to breed. Mrs. Kimleng hopes that the loan will improve her husband's business and increase the family's income to support its daily expenses. Mrs. Kimleng is pictured next to her husband who is sitting on the motorcycle with the trailer of icecream.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and five pigs to breed

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A., a married father of two children, was educated through Junior High level and has manufactured palm oil for sale at Cape Coast since 2005. His wife is a trader. Nana uses his income to pay for the upkeep of his family, and is now requesting a loan to purchase more ingredients for the mass production of palm oil. With the resulting additional profits from this expansion, Nana plans to reinvest in his business to increase sales, thereby eventually increasing his income.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for the mass production of palm oil.

loans.name: Maricela Del Carmen

texts.es:
Maricela C. es una dama muy esforzada que se dedica al negocio de pulpería el cual atiende muy amablemente en su casa de habitación ubicada en la ciudad de Masaya. Es importante destacar que ella es una dama muy alegre y con mucho ánimo de trabajar por lo que ha invertido en su negocio para mejorar su condición económica.

Hoy en día ella se ha refugiado en Ceprodel con el fin de obtener un crédito ya que su stock de inventario se le ha agotado y requiere la compra de dicha mercadería. Espera que su crédito le sea otorgado y de esta forma continuar con su negocio de pulpería en su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Maricela C. is a very hard-working woman who runs a small general store out of her home in the city of Masaya and she attends to her customers in a very friendly manner. It is important to highlight that she is a very happy person who is very excited to work because everything she invests in her business has helped to improve her economic conditions. Today she has sought out Ceprodel in order to receive a loan since she is running out of stock and she needs to buy more merchandise. She hopes to receive the loan in order to continue running her business out of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Soem

texts.en: Mrs. Soem K. is a 27-year-old rice farmer in Roung village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Moung Phat, owns a rice mill. Two of their three children attend the local school while the youngest is too young to work or study.  Because her land is infertile, Mrs. Soem Khoun has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer make her crop more productive.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sros

texts.en:
Sros Y., 36, is married and lives with four of her children and her husband in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works selling various kinds of vegetables in the market to earn a living and is able to make $3 of profit each day, while her husband is a pig breeder on a plot of land behind the house. On average, he makes $5 a day.

Sros Y. is asking a loan from Kiva of $1000 to expand by adding more pigs and purchase feed for them as well.

loans.use: Raise pigs and purchase feed

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen A. owns a shop selling provisions and plastic products and has been in business for twelve years. He procures his goods from Kumasi in Southern Ghana. His shop is strategically positioned at a junction where a lot of people pass by. Through experience, Stephen knows what products attract his customers and what they want. He is requesting a loan to have a bigger working capital to procure different kinds of goods and expand the size of his shop to  accommodate the variety of new goods. 

Stephen is 53 years old and married with six children, two males and four females. He says his youngest son is currently in  technical school and his adult children have completed school and are working.

loans.use: To buy provision and plastic products in bulk

loans.name: María

texts.es:
La dama María A. es originaria de la ciudad de León y se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de gaseosas, jugos y agua el cual posee en su propio local en el mercado La Terminal. Es importante destacar que Ceprodel le ha apoyado grandemente por la razón de que le ha brindado créditos que los ha utilizado en la compra de refrigeradoras y productos.

Hoy en día el motivo por el cual ha acudido a Ceprodel es para ser beneficiado con un crédito que le permita la compra de las bebidas. Es importante destacar que su mamá posee también un negocio de venta de comida y ambas se han destacado por ser excelentes comerciantes en su sector.
texts.en:
María A. comes from the city of León and works selling soft drinks, juices, and water at her own stand at the La Terminal market. It is important to point out that Ceprodel has given her great support by granting her loans that she has used to buy refrigerators and products. Now, she has come to Ceprodel because she would like a loan that allows her to purchase drinks. It is important to point out that her mother also has a business that sells food and both of these women are recognized as excellent business owners in their sector.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products

loans.name: Mwandawa

texts.en:
Mwandawa I. M. is a firewood and fruits seller in the Melinne neighborhood on the island of Zanzibar, Tanzania. She belongs to Takrima loan group (Group code 2034).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $40. Every day she sells firewood and fruits. She is hoping this loan will allow her to increase her profits and grow her business.  

Mwandawa is 28 years old, married with seven children: ages 13, 12, 11, 9, 7, 2 and 1.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and fruits for her business.

loans.name: Tavarali

texts.ru: Клиент Шомахмадов Таварали проживающий в районе А_Руми, в возрасте 53 -ех лет, женат имеет 8 детей, образования среднее.Сам клиент  не где  работает, он занимается животноводством более 16 лет. У него имеется несколько бычков.На получившие деньги клиент хочет преобрести несколько молодых бычков, с дольнейшей перепродажи.
texts.en:
Tavarali S. is a client who lives in the A-Rumi region. He is 53 years old, married and has eight children. He has secondary education. He does not have a job and runs an animal husbandry business for more than sixteen years. He has several calves. He will use the loan money to buy a few more young calves for future resale.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is 41 years old and married with 2 children. She sells medicines and provisions. She is requesting the loan amount of N 60,000 to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and provisions to sell

loans.name: Faveur Plus Group

texts.fr: Liliane L. habite dans une partie montagneuse à l’ouest de la ville de Kinshasa capitale de la RDC. C’est là où elle exerce ses activités commerciales.  Elle a commencé le commerce en 1983 quand elle était encore élève. Elle vendait chaque fois pendant les grandes vacances aux mois de juillet et août. Son capital initial était de $60 qui lui avaient permis d’acheter 1 sac de farine de manioc. Au fil des ans, Liliane a acquit une expérience solide pour la vente de la farine jusqu’à son mariage en 1989. Liliane a continué ses activités commerciales dans son foyer qui lui ont apporté un capital de $ 240 en 1993. Ses activités furent detruites par les pillages qui eurent lieu la même année. Après une période d’inactivité, elle relança son affaire de 2002 jusqu’à ce jour avec un capital de $60 toujours dans le secteur alimentaire. En août 2008, Liliane décide d’intégrer un des groupes de l’IMF Hope dans le but de diversifier son affaire en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Elle est une cliente fidèle de Hope qui a déjà reçu 2 crédits qu’elle a régulièrement et totalement remboursé. Le prêt qu’elle a obtenu ce mois d’avril lui a servi d’acheter 2 sacs de farine de manioc, elle a aussi diversifié son activité en y ajoutant des poissons fumés et salés à revendre afin d’augmenter le bénéfice. Liliane a 41 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants âgées de 5 à 19 ans dont l’ainé est indépendant et quatre vont à l’école. Son affaire lui génère un bénéfice de $ 15 par semaine et son ambition est d’ouvrir un jour un dépôt de farine de manioc et de maïs.
texts.en:
Liliane L. lives in a mountainous area west of the city of Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. That’s where she does business, which she started in 1983 when she was still a student. She used to sell during all the main vacation periods in July and August. Her $60 in initial capital had enabled her to buy a sack of cassava flour.

Over the years, she acquired solid experience in selling cassava flour until she was married in1989. She continued her commerce in her home, bringing $240 in capital in 1993. Her business was destroyed by pillaging that took place the same year. After a period of inactivity, she started up her business again from 2002 through the present with $60 in capital and in the food sector, still.

In August 2008, Liliane decided to join one of the groups of the micro-finance institution HOPE with the goal of diversifying her business and growing her revenues. She is a loyal customer of HOPE who has already had two loans that she repaid regularly and completely. The loan she obtained this April was used to buy two sacks of cassava flour. She also diversified her business by including smoked and salted fish for resale, so as to augment her profits.

Liliane is 41 years old, married, and the mother of five children, ages 5 to 19; the eldest is on his own, and four go to school. Her business generates for her a profit of $15 a week. Her ambition is to open an outlet one day for cassava flour and for corn.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 2 sacks of flour and to diversify her business by buying smoked and salted fish

loans.name: Ya Kaday Group

texts.en:
This is Ya Kaday S., Hawa Kondeh, Zainab K., Yeabu M. and Yeabu Conteh. They named their group Ya Kaday, after the group leader. They are local entrepreneurs in the City of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the sixth time they’ve received a loan through SMT. Previous loans have made significant contributions to the well-being of these entrepreneurs. Having repaid their last loan successfully, Ya Kaday is requesting a new loan to further enable them to strengthen their businesses by buying more products.

Ya Kaday (second from left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-three years of age. She was born in Gbojibu, in eastern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have four children – two secondary schoolers and two in primary schools. Ya Kaday sells ready-to-wear-clothes, dishes, mobile phones, etc. – in Makeni. She has been in this business for more than five years now.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Kaggwa

texts.en: Kaggwa K. is a 34 year old, married man with four children. He sells fish and has a fish stall in Kalisizo main market. He also owns SANYU Restaurant located in Kalisizo main market. He is using the loan to purchase a refrigerator, food items for the restaurant and better quality fishing nets for his fish business. His future hope is to make a bigger restaurant and expand his market stall for fish and to start transporting the fish both to Kampala and Kasese.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator, food items for the restaurant and better quality fishing nets for his fish business.

loans.name: Okerike

texts.en:
Okerike M. is 32 years old and is married. He sells provisions.

Okerike hopes for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. 

He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Lương Thị

texts.en:
Huệ Lương Thị (231011429) is a 30-year-old female living in the town of Sóc Sơn. She is married and has three school-aged children.

Huệ owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month.

In 2001, Huệ joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase pig feed and other supplies.

Huệ is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her 8th from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Suyar

texts.en:
M. Suyar has a responsibility that makes him work hard for improvement. He is farmer. He grows onions and potatoes. He is hopeful of making progress with this work to provide what is necessary for his family's needs. For that reason, he wants to invest in his production, expand his crop fields and improve the quality of his products. 

Suyar knows that if he takes care of his land and works diligently he will reap excellent products that will have a better reception in the marketplace. The request Suyar makes is to purchase fertilizers necessary for his land. Support this hardworking man so his effort is worthwhile.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Lea Esmeralda

texts.es: Lea Esmeralda C. B. reside en Colon municipio del departamento de La Libertad. Lea vive con su padre, hermanas, y  su madre quien le ayuda en el negocio. Lea tiene 25 años de edad es una mujer muy trabajadora y de fe en Dios, Lea ayuda a sus padres por medio de su negocio ubicado en su casa una tienda de productos de consumo, pero como que no fuese suficiente trabajo Lea también se dedica a la confección de ropa a la medida, elabora todo tipo de vestuario para damas, el crédito que solicita Lea es para invertirlo en la tienda surtiéndolo de cereales, bebidas y boquitas, para lograr obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Lea Esmeralda C. B. lives in the Colon municipality in the La Libertad department. Lea lives with her father, sisters, and mother; who she helps with the business. Lea is 25, and she is a very hard working woman with faith in God. Lea helps her parents in their business, which is located in their house. Their store sells consumable items. As if this was not enough work, Leah also makes custom clothes. She makes every type of clothing for women. The loan Lea is asking for is to invest in the store and stock it with grains, drinks, and snacks in order to get greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Norma Alicia

texts.es: “Manejo una cooperativa (tiendita)dentro de una universidad, en esta época han bajado las ventas y me gustaría invertir en mercancía para poder tener mas ganancias, tengo aproximadamente 5 años con este negocio tanto los estudiantes de la escuela como los maestros me conocen y saben que soy una persona trabajadora y que vivo del ingreso que mi negocio me da”
texts.en:
“I manage a cooperative (general store) inside a university. Since sales have been low lately, I would like to invest in merchandise for my store to increase my earnings. I’ve had this business for five years. The university students and teachers know me well. They know that I am a hard-working person and that I live from the income generated by my business.”

Translated from Spanish by Rina Paguaga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in merchandise for her store

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia is 32 years old.  She an d her family are living in the village of Arcon, Tumauini, Isabela. She is married to Elmer, a tricycle driver and they have three children: Erwin,12 years old, elementary student; Emerson, 11 years old , also in elementary level and Erick Jay, 3 years old. Leticia is working hard so she can able to help her husband in providing the needs of their family especially to meet the needs of their children.  
 
Leticia is engaged in the vending business.  She sells fish, food snacks and vegetables in their village. She also sells different items such as fruits whenever she has extra capital to use. She sells her products in three neighboring villages and she is able to earn a daily net income of PHP500.00.  Fish vending is her first business until she was able to expand into vegetables, fruits and snacks. 

She hopes to further improve it and hoping to have her own stall in their village. She would like to borrow a loan of PHP4, 000 from KIVA lenders that she can use in the business.  Leticia dreams of having her own general store in the future for bigger income.  She hopes to attain all her dreams by starting to save some of her profits from her existing business and with the help of lenders. She is praying that God may help her reach her dreams.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna A. is from the village of Kabulawan in Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. Lorna is married. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store where she sells a variety of foods and daily-use products, such as shampoo, in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP that she will use to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Lorna's 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy new items to sell

loans.name: Lil Joy

texts.en:
For almost four years, Lil Joy has operated a chicken, frozen products and fish selling business at a public market. Her weekly net income is PHP 1,000.00. She has also had a retail store for almost ten years and a livestock business of hog raising. She is asking for a loan of PHP 23,000.00 from KIVA lenders in order to have additional working capital to buy more chicken to sell.

She is married to Eliseo, a principal at Culing Centro National High School. They are blessed with three children: Kristel Joy- 22 years of age, a college graduate; Krisha Eloisa - 17 years of age, a second year college student, and their youngest, Kristan Ryne - 5 years of age, a preschooler. They are currently residing at Culing Sentro, two kilometers away from the national highway. She hopes and prays that KIVA lenders will grant her the loan to allow her to meet her family needs and to support the education of their children.

loans.use: To buy more chicken meat.

loans.name: Carren Achieng

texts.en:
Carren Achieng is an industrious and enterprising lady. She is 42 years old. She is married to Francis, a retiree. Carren has been in the tailoring and dressmaking business for the last three years. She feels that her business would have grown much faster had she started taking out loans earlier.

She learned about KADET Ltd through a member of her local church. This is her second loan from KADET Ltd. With the loan, Carren intends to purchase materials to complete two orders for bride and bridesmaid dresses. 

She aspires to open a big boutique in the future.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more materials to make bridal and bridesmaid gowns

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: A. Odette est née en 1956 et réside au quartier Houénoussou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis onze ans. C'est une veuve ayant cinq enfants tous scolarisés, mais dont trois sont à sa charge. Odette vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Odette n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Odette mène depuis onze ans comme activité, la vente de divers articles (pâtes alimentaires, conserves, liqueurs, tomate  en boîte, petits pois, lait, bougies, papiers hygiéniques, tomate, piments, etc.) à son domicile. Odette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et à Bohicon au Bénin. Odette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Odette voudrait diversifier davantage son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est pourquoi, Odette sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Odette was born in 1956 and has been residing for 11 years in the Houénoussou district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widow with five children who are all in school. She is financially responsible for three of them. She lives alone with her children and is the sole breadwinner of the family. Odette never attended school. To support herself, she has been running a business out of her home for 11 years selling a variety of goods (pasta, canned food, liqueurs, canned tomatoes, peas, milk, candles, toilet paper, tomatoes, chili peppers, etc.) She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international marketplace of Benin, and in Bohicon in Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client, having already had two loans, which were repaid. She would like to diversify her business further and to respond better to the demands of her customers. This is why she's requesting a third ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of soap, pasta, cassava flour, and canned foods

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
La señora Andrea es socia del Banco Comunal “Jesús de Nazaret”, en el distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno, tiene 40 años, es conviviente,  tiene 04 hijos, 02 de ellos están en Tacna y 02 están  estudiando,  ella no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 3 años, se dedica a  la compra y venta de ganado desde que ingreso al Banco Comunal, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 con el que compró 02 ovinos porque no alcanzaba para comprar ganado vacuno. Paralelo a ello también realiza actividades agrícolas  para autoconsumo.

Ella solicitará el monto de S/. 2000.00 Nuevos Soles, con ello comprará 01 toro para engordarlo en 03 meses para luego venderlo en la feria de ganado.

Indica que en su  Banco Comunal aprende y se olvida de sus tristezas.

Su anhelo es tener su tienda de abarrotes ya que tiene una casa en la plaza del Centro Poblado de López.
texts.en:
Andrea is a member of the “Jesús de Nazaret” [Jesus of Nazareth] communal bank, in Ilave district, Collao province, Puno department. She is 40 years old, lives with her partner, and has 4 children. Two of her children live in Tacna and 2 are studying. She did not have the opportunity to study. She has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos [Kiva Field Partner] for 3 years. Since joining the communal bank she has been buying and selling livestock. Her first loan was for PEN 300.00 and she bought 2 sheep because she didn’t have enough to buy a cow. Along with this business, she also does agricultural activities for home consumption. She is requesting the amount of PEN 2,000.00, which she will use to buy 1 bull to fatten him up within 3 months so she can then sell him at the cattle market. She says that in her communal bank she learns and she forgets her problems. Her hope is to have a small grocery store because she a house on the plaza in Centro Poblado de López.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a bull

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase new goods to improve business.

loans.name: Nancy Janela

texts.es:
Con mucha experiencia en el trabajo de pulpería, la señora Nancy S. se dedica a la venta de productos varios tales como granos básicos, productos personales y comestibles ofrecidos en su pulpería que ha logrado surtir a medida que el tiempo ha venido transcurriendo. Ella se ha destacado por ser muy trabajadora y por brindar buenas condiciones de vida a su familia.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de los granos básicos, pollo y gaseosas para continuar ofreciéndolos en la pulpería y de esta forma garantizar la satisfacción de sus clientes.
texts.en:
With much experience in running a small grocery, Mrs. Nancy S. is dedicated to the sale of various products, such as basic grains, personal items, and groceries which her store has offered for some time. She has acquired a reputation as hard-working and for providing good conditions of life for her family.

She is requesting a loan to buy basic grains, chicken, and soft drinks, so that she can continue offering them in her grocery store and in this manner, guarantee the satisfaction of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY BASIC GRAINS, CHICKEN, AND SOFT DRINKS TO SELL

loans.name: Karel Tatiana

texts.es: La joven Karel Tatiana tiene una farmacia ubicada en su casa de  habitación desde hace 3 años, ella es una persona muy emprendedora pues disfruta mucho interactuar con sus clientes, por lo que alguna veces le solicitan consejos acerca de las medicinas. A pesar de los diferentes problemas que ha enfrentado como es la competencia pero la mayoría de sus clientes son sus vecinos y otros son amigo y familiares de ella. Solicita un financiamiento para la compra de diversidad de medicamentos, ya que esta farmacia es bien solicitada por los clientes, debido a que los precios del medicamento son más favorables que en otras, gracias a Dios y a su arduo esfuerzo a podido salir adelante. Su deseo es que sus hijos logren finalizar sus estudios.
texts.en:
Karel Tatiana has been managing a pharmacy out of her home for the past three years. She is an enterprising person who enjoys interacting with her customers who seek her advice about medicines. Despite encountering different problems, including the competition, she continues to serve her customers who are mostly neighbors, friends, and relatives.

She is requesting a loan in order to buy a variety of medicines. Her pharmacy is frequented by her customers because the prices of her medicines are more affordable than other places. Thanks to God and her hard work, she has been able to get ahead. Her wish is to see her children finish school.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase medicines

loans.name: Norng

texts.en:
Mrs. Norng P. is highly skilled at planting crops in the village. For extra profit, she also buys mature crops from other farmers to resell. She has another partner in her husband, who appears in the photo. He built a workshop and has some tools that he uses to provide vehicle repair services in front of his house. Mrs. Norng P. has four children. Three of her children are married and live independently, and the other one is single. 

Norng P.’s husband is very busy at his trade because there are a lot of clients who need his service, but he lacks essential tools to perform his service, so Norng P. has requested a loan to buy more tools. She hopes to use any remains from the loan to increase the financing of her rice sales enterprise.

loans.use: To buy more tools for her husband's vehicle repair business

loans.name: Anasii

texts.en:
Anasii S. is 56 and married with 6 children (ages 12 - 33).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Anasii has 1 year of experience in this business.  Anasii needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at:   http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

In 2010, Anasii joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Anasii's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Anasii S. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna S. is currently in the business of selling various foods in a restaurant like beans, rice, beef, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and soda to sell. Anna is 25 years old and is married with a husband that is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

Anna S. is the one in front and is seated in the white plastic chair.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy crates of beer and soda to sell.

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia is 31 years old and married with two children who attend school.  She has been running a green grocery for nine years.  She has one employee who assists her in the business.  She has always distinguished herself as being a very hardworking person and devoted to her family. She was previously selling charcoal before her capital increased and she opened this business. She hopes to open many outlets and improve her living standards in the future. She has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to expand her business and open a kiosk.

loans.use: To open a kiosk

loans.name: Virgen Natividad Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Virgen de Natividad inicia su primer ciclo con 8 socias.
Las socias son del distrito de Tambo, Provincia de La Mar, ellas realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de ropa, queso, leche, crianza de animales, entre otros.
Como es el caso de la Señora Ylda que es casada, tiene 5 hijos que están estudiando, Ylda se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno de otras personas, de las cuales obtiene leche para luego hacer quesos, su préstamo será invertido en el alquiler de terrenos de alfalfa para la alimentación del ganado.
Los sueños de Ylda es tener terreno suficiente para no alquilar.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 200 soles, 300 soles, 400 soles, 1000 soles haciendo un total de 3,600 soles.
texts.en:
The Virgen de Natividad communal bank is made up of 8 members who are beginning their first loan cycle. The members are based in the Tambo district in the province of La Mar. They have different businesses such as selling clothes, selling milk and cheese, and raising livestock. For example, Ylda is married and has 5 children who are in school. She makes a living raising cattle that belong to other people—she collects milk from the cows for making cheese. She is going to use the loan to rent alfalfa fields for feeding the cattle. Ylda’s dream is to have enough land so that she won’t have to rent anymore. The members need different loan amounts—such as 200 soles, 300 soles, 400 soles, and 1000 soles—which add up to a total of 3,600 soles for the group.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Renting alfalfa fields for feeding cattle

loans.name: Ma. Edelita

texts.en:
Ma. Edelita F. is 44 years old and resides in Binangonan which is located in the province of Rizal. She lives with her husband, who works as a controller, and their three dependent children.

Ma. Edelita has a store in her house where she sells basic necessities and all types of products that people use in their homes. She is requesting a loan so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales.

Ma. Edelita’s business is very important because it enables her to provide better financial stability for her family to live in a decent manner. She hopes to provide them with everything necessary to move forward against poverty. She dreams of the best for her family: to have an expanded business and to have a happy family.

Ma. Edelita has shown herself to be hard-working and strong-minded to make her dreams come true and she is hoping that her business will continue to be more productive and improve the overall quality of living of her entire family.

loans.use: To buy more food products and basic household necessities for her store

loans.name: Francis V.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a secondary school in Grafton, near Freetown. This school was opened in 2005 by the Sierra Leone International Mission (SLIM) to educate the children of Grafton, especially children affected by the war. Currently, the school is staffed with four teachers on its payroll and three SLIM-assisted teachers. The school has a population of 116 pupils.  

This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of "Shine on Sierra Leone" in Waterloo, to seek a loan in order to supplement their monthly salaries.  With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not have been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Francis V. B. (pictured left) is the head teacher at the school and leader of this group of borrowers. Forty-five-year-old Francis was born in Kailahum, eastern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have five children – two in secondary school and three in primary school. 

In addition to his teaching profession, Mr. B. also does some petty trading. He has been a petty-businessman for over fifteen years (even before joining the teaching profession).  Francis has applied for a loan of SLL 800,000. With this loan, he will buy gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm-oil to add to his business inventory

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Neang T., 50, is widowed and resides with her four children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, the most populated city in the country. She sells groceries and clothes for an income of about USD 7 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to buy more clothes to expand the current business. In the future she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en: Eliza C. is from the village of Marcos. She is 37 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Eliza owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eleven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Eliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Eliza is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria L. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Gloria is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Gloria raises crops. The main source of income for her business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gloria has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. Gloria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI, a Kiva partner. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Gloria from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Lucile

texts.en:
Lucile O. is a 46 year old married woman who supports her family by selling cell phone accessories and phone card reloading business. She lives in Tambongon, San Remegio, Cebu City with her husband and their 2 children who are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her selling of cell phone accessories and cell phone card reloading business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 5,000.

Lucile is borrowing Php 29,500 so that she could use it as an additional working capital for her businesses. This will be her 8th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lucile aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Redford

texts.en:
Redford Z. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 21 years old and married. To make a living, Redford owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Redford has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Redford joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Redford is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Redford from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 41 years old.  She has twelve children that range from the age of 12 months to 24 years.  Eight of her children are in school while the rest are not yet of school age. Her husband sells food crops.

Jeannette sells fabrics and has been in this business for 12 years.  She needs a loan to expand her business.  She plans to buy more fabrics in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: Buying more fabrics

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine L. is from the village of Rizal. She is 37 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Geraldine owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest. In 2007, Geraldine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Geraldine is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 7th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: BUYING AUTO PARTS FOR HIS REPAIR SHOP AND PAINT AND CEMENT FOR HIS BEDROOM

loans.name: Soam

texts.en: Mrs. Soam T., age 56, lives in Kompong Chhnang province. She has been spending most of her life farming rice crops. Soam T. learned this specific skill from her grandparent when she was young. She is married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She currently resides with three children. One of her children has a suitable job and the other two are single. Soam T. is taking out her loan to buy a secondhand motor for her employed children to drive to work. Any remaining cash from the loan she will use towards sustaining her crops.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motor.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia G. is currently in the business of baking local Sudanese bread such as tamia, gelabia etc and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour to sell.  Cecilia is 30 years old and is married to an army man. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann S. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 42 years old. Mary Ann is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Mary Ann joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rit's Group

texts.en:
Four members make up this group loan in Samraong K'aer village in Kandal province, where they live. They all have selected Mrs. Rit H., 48 years old, to be group leader.  They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Rit H. and her husband, Mr. Taroem Ben, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow some rice to sell and some rice to support their family.  They own an agricultural machine. Her rice field is far away from irrigation system and has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Rit H. is applying for a loan to buy gasoline and fertilizer. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are helping their parents’ businesses, while the others are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy gasoline and fertilizer

loans.name: Abel Rodolfo

texts.es:
Abel de 55 años, tiene una panadería y también vende algunos víveres de primera necesidad. Vive en una zona urbana llamada suburbio de Guayaquil y caracterizada porque la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes. 

Hace 10 años atrás tuvo la necesidad de tener un negocio ya que tenía 5 hijos que estaban pequeños, pero como vivía en “Valsar” (un cantón fuera de Guayaquil) no tenía muchas oportunidades de tener su negocio. Cuando sus hijos se graduaron el fue a vivir a Guayaquil y como no encontró trabajo opto por tener su panadería y la surtió con algunos víveres para que sea más atrayentes para las personas. En la actualidad trabaja desde las 16h00 hasta las 17h00 haciendo la masa de los panes y a partir del día siguiente a las 05h30 hasta las 10h00am comienza a vender los panes.   

Con el préstamo quiere comprar harina, manteca para tener la oportunidad de hacer más panes para su negocio. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa y mejorar su panadería.
texts.en: Abel is 55 years old and has a bakery where he also sells some groceries of primary need. He lives in a densely populated suburb of Guayaquil where the majority of the inhabitants are merchants. He saw the necessity of having a business 10 years ago because he had five young children, but since he was living in Valsar (a village outside of Guayaquil) he did not have a lot of opportunities. When his children graduated he went to live in Guayaquil and since he couldn't find work he decided to start his bakery and stocked it with some groceries so he could attract more people. He currently works from 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. making dough for his bread and on the following day he starts selling the breads from 5:30 a.m. until 10 a.m. With the loan he wants to purchase flour and lard so he can make more bread for his business. In the future he wants to finish construction on his home and make improvements to his bakery.

loans.use: Flour, lard

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes de este comité  se dedican a variadas actividades entre las que se puede destacar  la venta de ropas, minutas, como empanadas, tortillas, croqueta, asaditos de carne etc. y  otras actividades. 
La  mayoría   son madres de familia y  cabezas de hogar por lo que día a día se sacrifican mucho para salir adelante
 Este comité se encuentra en su 8vo ciclo en donde se puede destacar el sentido de responsabilidad y los deseos de progresar que tienen cada una de las integrantes en la asistencia en las capacitaciones. 
 Desean que sus hijos no pasen por las mismas limitaciones laborales y educativas por eso se esfuerzan el doble para poder brindar a sus hijos oportunidades de progreso.
Una de las integrantes, una señora muy trabajadora Celina quien se dedica a la recolección y venta de productos que se reciclen como plásticos y papeles. 
Ella hace un recorrido por los barrios diariamente para recolectar las basuras que se pueden reciclar en una carretilla que posee y una vez que cuenta con buena cantidad lo lleva par la venta y así obtiene el ingreso para su familia. 
Ella forma se encuentra muy satisfecha por formar parte del comité y solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías de consumo para su familia como carne, aceite, harina, fideos, frutas y verduras.
texts.en:
The members of this committee engage in a number of business activities including clothes sales, sales of flavored ice drinks, empanadas, tortillas, croquettes, grilled meat, etc.

Most of the group's members are mothers and heads of their households.  For this reason, they work hard every day to get ahead.

This committee is entering its 8th loan cycle.  Every member has a sense of responsibility and a desire to make progress.  They all attend their training sessions.  They would like to avoid their children having to suffer the same work and educational limitations that they did and so they work doubly hard to provide their children with opportunities for progress.

One of the group's members, a very hard-working lady called Celina, works collecting and selling recyclable products such as plastic and paper.  She passes through neighborhoods daily to collect garbage that can be recycled.  She collects these products in a little cart that she owns and once she has a good quantity, she takes it all to sell and earn income for her family.

Celina is very happy to be a part of her committee and she is requesting a loan to buy food for her family such as meat, oil, flour, noodles, fruit and vegetables.

loans.use: To buy meat, oil, flour, noodles, fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Asoc.de Mujeres Ama De Casa Group

texts.es:
El comité “Asoc.ama de casa” se formó con la unión de varias vecinas de Capiibary-4 de Mayo. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, Despensa, cría de animales.
  Las integrantes formaron un grupo muy unido y capaz de realizar conjuntamente actividades que fortalecen su compañerismo y al adquirir el crédito se le abren muchas puertas Para el progreso de sus emprendimiento. 
Margarita T. de Quiñonez es la Presidenta del grupo  es una señora  muy emprendedora, le gusta  la organización por eso  se le eligieron como cabeza de grupo. 
Ella posee una despensa y crías de animales (como chancho, gallinas etc.
Tiene 52 años con dos hijos. Todos mayores de edad.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de alimento para los animales.
texts.en:
The group named "Asoc. Ama de Casa" is made up of several neighbors who live in Capibary, 4 de Mayo. Each of the members of the group carries out their own business, including sales, convenience store, and livestock farming. 

The members came together and formed a much unified group that is capable of carrying out activities that support their common goals, especially in the acquisition of loans. Loans have opened many doors and with this help they have seen progress in their businesses.

Margarita T. de Quinonez is the leader of the group and she is a very enterprising person. She enjoys organizing which is the reason why she was chosen to be the leader of the group. 

She has a convenience store and she also raises livestock (including pigs, chickens, etc). She is 52 years old and she has 2 grown children. She requests a loan to purchase feed for her livestock.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida B. is from the village of Camarag San Isidro, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Aida is married and has 3 grown children. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 32000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Aida is requesting a new loan of 27000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
This is 33 year-old Leonard. He is married and has no children. Leonard established his pharmaceutical drugs business because he wants to become a pharmacist. Leonard operates his business 6 days a week and 10 hours a day. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000.000 in order to buy more medicine. In the future, Leonard plans to grow his business. He would also like to tell others about how the loan has helped him. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more drugs to sell

loans.name: Yama De Amor 1, 2, 3 & 4 Group

texts.es:
Maria es una D. los miembros del grupo Yama D. Amor 1, 2, 3 & 4. Su familia está compuesta por 3 hijos y su esposo, ambos (padre y madre) han educado y criado a sus hijos. Nos dice que sus retos o desafíos más difíciles es cumplir su meta D. tener un buen negocio, que genera buenos ingresos tanto para ella como para su comunidad, sea por medio D. empleos, o por buenos precios.

Maria está muy emocionada D. recibir su 12th préstamo en Esperanza Internacional. Ella ha tenido su negocio por alrededor D. 7 años, el cual inicio cuando el programa D. Esperanza llego a su comunidad. Maria está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra D. alimentos como arroz, habichuelas, azúcar, vegetales, aceite, y carnes. Ella va a utilizar sus ganancias para seguir invirtiendo en su negocio para mejorar sus ventas, incorporando mas productos y también para ahorrar. Deseo en un futuro no muy lejano poder lograr su sueño D. poder terminar D. construir su casa, también desea tener buena salud y tener una vida más estable económicamente.

Fotos divididas, para poder mostrar mas rostros, en la foto se muestran las 15 mujeres del prestamo.
texts.en:
María is a member of the “Yama D. Amor 1, 2, 3 y 4” (Flame of Love 1, 2, 3, & 4) group.  Her family is maD. up of her husband and three children.  Both (mother and father) have educated and raised their children.  She tells us that her most difficult challenge is to reach her goal of having a good business that generates good income both for her and for her community be it through jobs or good prices.

María is very excited about getting her 12th loan in Esperanza Internacional.  She’s had a business for about 7 years which joined the Esperanza program when it came to the community.  María is planning on investing her new loan in the purchase of foodstuffs like: rice, beans, sugar, vegetables, oil and meats.  She will use her profits to continue investing in her business to improve sales incorporating more products and also to save.  She hopes in a not too distant future to have her dream of building her house come true; she also wants to have good health and a more economically stable life.

Photos are divided in order to show more faces.  In the photo are shown the fifteen women of the loan.

loans.use: For rice, beans, sugar, vegetables, oil and meats.

loans.name: Ruos' Group

texts.en:
Four people are forming this village loan. They are located in Khsom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Ruos M., born in 1970, was selected to be the group leader by the other members. 

She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to grow rice and different vegetables for selling to help support their family. 

This couple has two children who are students and also help their parents in farming. 

In order to support this farming, Mrs. Ruos M. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticide.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticide .

loans.name: Nakali

texts.en:
Nakali D. is 42 years old, married, and has two children.  In 2000, she established her grocery store business.  Working seven days a week, eight hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to buy groceries for her shop.  In the future, Nakali plans to expand the business.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called pasal, are an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 square. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: To purchase grocery goods

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya, 49, is married and lives with her husband and a daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small rented plot of land. 

Tuya began selling clothes at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in the city, in 1999. Her monthly sales range up to 1,900,000 MNT and her current working capital exceeds 800,000 MNT, in addition to her inventory. She pays 36,000 MNT for the monthly rent of the stall. She goes to China to purchase consumer goods once or twice a month depending on her sales volume. 

Tuya is a responsible and modest person who says, "we want to build a house where we can have a comfortable life in the future". She is requesting a loan of 1,700,000 MNT to purchase more consumer goods for her business.

loans.use: purchase more consumer goods to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice N. was born in 1966; she is married to Vincent Tih Forsuh and is blessed with five children. She shares three rooms with her five children in Ayaba Street, a quarter in the Bamenda North West Region of Cameroon.

Alice has faced difficulties in her life ranging from the inability to meet her daily needs, the inability of her husband to get a job for himself nor carry out any activity that could raise income due to an accident, the inability of her first son to continue his education due to poverty, and the increasing demands of her children. Amongst other challenges, she also has had difficulties of inadequate capital to expand her business.

With this loan, she plans to buy more food stuff like rice, beans, and cocoa yams to cook to sell in her restaurant. She also plans to piglets and feed to open up a pig farm. She thinks her business will succeed, because her business site is close to the road and she is friendly, thus has many clients. Her activity will help her community in reducing the cost of transportation to buy foods in the market and their cordial relationship will give room for negotiation to pay later.

She will use a fraction of her profit to assist her husband, provide for the children’s school needs, meet her personal needs and that of her family. She prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the training she frequently receives, the follow up and moral support given her by the GHAPE office, and the low cost in obtaining and paying back a loan.

About GHAPE:
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy rice beans, piglets and feed

loans.name: Cristo Salvador Group

texts.es: La Sra. Rosalinda es casada y tiene 3 hijos, Rosalinda es integrante D. la alcancía comunal “Cristo Salvador ” grupo conformado por 9 socios que se dedican a actividades D. comercio, Rosalinda  alquila mototaxi  desD. hace 5 años este  trabajo surge a raíz D. que ella quería conseguir  mejores  ingresos y   darle trabajo a mucha gente y es así que  gracias  a su esfuerzo y dedicación se ha comprado muebles, equipo D. sonido, escritorio , y sus hijos tienen una buena educación y sobre todo darles una buena calidad D. vida a sus hijos, por que sin ellos no hubiera tenido la fuerza para conseguir todo lo que hoy en día tiene. El préstamo que  se le otorgo fue para  darle mantenimiento  a sus motos. Sabemos que Rosalinda  cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos D. Edaprospo la ayudaran.
texts.en: Mrs. Rosalinda is married and has three children. She is a member of the “Cristo Salvador” (Christ the Savior) Community Bank. This group is maD. up of nine members that are businesspeople. Rosalinda rents motor-taxis. In the past five years this business has grown so much that Rosalinda has increased her earnings and provided work for a lot of people. Thanks to her dedication and effort she has purchased furniture, sound equipment and a desk. Her children have had a good education. Above everything, these earnings have improved the quality of life for her children. If it weren’t for her efforts, they wouldn’t have everything that they have today. The loan that she is requesting will be used for motor-taxi maintenance. We know that Rosalinda reaches her goals through much work and effort and this loan from Edaprospo will help her.

loans.use: to maintain a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Alma Rosa

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la  señora Alma Rosa le está haciendo falta un cuarto. 
Esta solicitando préstamo para poder comprar el material que es block, varilla, cemento y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de la construcción.
Planea pagar el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene de su trabajo como vendedora de servicios funerales, ya que su esposo se encargara de los gastos familiares en el sueldo que recibe de su trabajo como chofer de un camión de carga.
Desean que el nuevo hijo que están esperando tenga su propia recamara y espacio en la casa donde el pueda estar sin que lo molestan y donde pueda jugar.
texts.en:
The home of Sra. Alma Rosa is lacking a room. She is requesting a loan to buy materials such as blocks, rods, cement, as well as to pay someone to handle the construction.

Alma plans to repay the loan using the earnings from her job selling funeral services. Her husband will take care of the family expenses with the salary he receives from his job as a truck driver. They are expecting a new baby and would like for their child to have a bedroom and a space to play without bothering anyone.

loans.use: to purchase materials to finish the construction of a bedroom.

loans.name: Wilfredo Antonio

texts.es:
Wilfredo Antonio se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general. Tiene más de 7 años en su negocio. Su negocio dio inicio porque no tenía la oportunidad de proporcionarle a su familia ingresos diariamente, fue con muy poco capital que logro empezar este medio de vida. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de ropa en general, calzado, perfumes, lápiz labial y más productos. 

En un futuro quiere ver a sus hijos profesionales y que no pasen por el trabajo duro como él lo ha hecho.
texts.en:
Wilfredo Antonio is a general goods vendor and has been in business for seven years.  He started his business because he had no other means of income to support his family.  With a little bit of capital he got started.  The requested loan is to buy general clothing, shoes, perfumes, lipstick and other products.  

He wants to see his children become professionals so they don't have to go through the same type of hard work that he has had to.

loans.use: To buy clothing, shoes, perfumes, lipstick and other products.

loans.name: Hilario

texts.es: Hilario, de 53 años, esta casado con Enedina, ambos tiene 5 hijos, todos ellos menores de edad educados en su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad de Pian. Su familia es su principal pilar para salir adelante. Él es albañil y todos los días trabaja para poder ayudar en los gastos diarios de la familia; mientras que su esposa Enedina se dedica a la ganadería, pero el momento más importante para ellos es cuando se encuentran en el campo, donde siembran espinaca y gladiolos hace ya 40 años.  Viajar a la capital de su país para vender sus productos y realizar su oficio de constructor de casas es lo que más le gusta a Hilario, ya que puede comprar muchas cosas que no encuentra en su pueblo, es por ello que piensa poner una tienda de abarrotes, cuando aumente su capital. En adelante desea construir una casa en la capital para sus hijos, para que tengan un lugar donde se queden mientras estudian en la universidad.  Agradecer a Dios por darle vitalidad y fuerzas para trabajar, ya que forma a su familia bajo esa doctrina. Él pertenece al banco comunal “Sarita Colonia”, y este es el noveno crédito con MFP, donde espera obtener el pequeño crédito para realizar sus objetivos.
